nexttext:
\noindent where $G_5$ is the Newton's constant in five dimensions,  the dilaton field $\Phi$ is given by $\Phi = kz^2$, where $k \sim \Lambda^2_{QCD}$ and $V_G$ is the dilatonic potential. 
The metric tensor in 5-dimensional space has the following form $g^s_{mn} = b^2_s(z)(dz^2 + \eta_{\mu \nu}dx^\mu dx^\nu)$ with  $0 \leq z \leq \infty$, $m,n = 0,1,2,3,4\; , \;\mu, \nu = 0,1,2,3 \;{\rm and} \; \eta_{\mu \nu} =$ diag $(-1, 1, 1, 1)$ and $b_s(z) \equiv e^{A_s(z)}$. All of these parameters are in the string frame. 
The precise form of the metric will be defined solving the equations of motion and finding explicitly the expression for $A_s(z)$. Actually, it is easier to solve this problem in the Einstein frame. 

Performing a Weyl rescaling,  from the string frame to the Einstein frame, such that
$b_E (z) = b_s(z)e^{-\frac{2}{3}\Phi(z)} = e^{A_E(z)}$ and $A_E(z) = A_s(z) - \frac{2}{3}\Phi(z)$, 
 one can rewrite the action (\ref{acao_corda}) as:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="S=\frac{G_{5}^{-1}}{16\pi}\int d^{5}x\sqrt{-g_{s}}\;e^{-2\Phi(z)}({\cal R}_{s}%
+4\partial_{M}\Phi\partial^{M}\Phi-V^{s}_{G}(\Phi))" display="block"><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><msubsup><mi>G</mi><mn>5</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mn>16</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>5</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+2.8pt"><msqrt><mrow><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>g</mi><mi>s</mi></msub></mrow></msqrt></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℛ</mi><mi>s</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msub><mo>∂</mo><mi>M</mi></msub><mo>⁡</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msup><mo>∂</mo><mi>M</mi></msup><mo>⁡</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>V</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>s</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext:
\noindent where $G_5$ is the Newton's constant in five dimensions,  the dilaton field $\Phi$ is given by $\Phi = kz^2$, where $k \sim \Lambda^2_{QCD}$ and $V_G$ is the dilatonic potential. 
The metric tensor in 5-dimensional space has the following form $g^s_{mn} = b^2_s(z)(dz^2 + \eta_{\mu \nu}dx^\mu dx^\nu)$ with  $0 \leq z \leq \infty$, $m,n = 0,1,2,3,4\; , \;\mu, \nu = 0,1,2,3 \;{\rm and} \; \eta_{\mu \nu} =$ diag $(-1, 1, 1, 1)$ and $b_s(z) \equiv e^{A_s(z)}$. All of these parameters are in the string frame. 
The precise form of the metric will be defined solving the equations of motion and finding explicitly the expression for $A_s(z)$. Actually, it is easier to solve this problem in the Einstein frame. 

Performing a Weyl rescaling,  from the string frame to the Einstein frame, such that
$b_E (z) = b_s(z)e^{-\frac{2}{3}\Phi(z)} = e^{A_E(z)}$ and $A_E(z) = A_s(z) - \frac{2}{3}\Phi(z)$, 
 one can rewrite the action (\ref{acao_corda}) as:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="S=\frac{G_{5}^{-1}}{16\pi}\int d^{5}x\sqrt{-g_{E}}\;({\cal R}_{E}-\frac{4}{3}%
\partial_{m}\Phi\partial^{m}\Phi-V^{E}_{G}(\Phi))" display="block"><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><msubsup><mi>G</mi><mn>5</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mn>16</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>5</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+2.8pt"><msqrt><mrow><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>g</mi><mi>E</mi></msub></mrow></msqrt></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℛ</mi><mi>E</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msub><mo>∂</mo><mi>m</mi></msub><mo>⁡</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msup><mo>∂</mo><mi>m</mi></msup><mo>⁡</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>V</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>E</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: \noindent and the equations of motion are:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="S=\int d^{5}x\sqrt{-g_{s}}\;\frac{1}{2}e^{-\Phi(z)}[\partial_{M}{\cal G}%
\partial^{M}{\cal G}+M^{2}_{5}{\cal G}^{2}]" display="block"><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>5</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+2.8pt"><msqrt><mrow><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>g</mi><mi>s</mi></msub></mrow></msqrt></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mo>∂</mo><mi>M</mi></msub><mo>⁡</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒢</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msup><mo>∂</mo><mi>M</mi></msup><mo>⁡</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒢</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>M</mi><mn>5</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒢</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Representing the scalar field through a $4d$ Fourier transform ${\cal \tilde{G}}(q,z)$ and performing a change of function ${\cal \tilde{G}} = \psi (z) e^{\frac{B(z)}{2}}$, where $B(z) = \Phi(z) - 3A_s(z) $, one gets the following $1d$ Schr\"odinger-like equation

\begin{eqnarray}\label{equ_7_new1}
 - \psi''(z) + V(z) \psi(z) = (- q^2 )\psi(z)\,,
\end{eqnarray}
\noindent where the effective potential is given by 
\begin{eqnarray}\label{V(z)}
 V(z) =  k^2 z^2 + \frac{15}{4z^2}  - 2k 
 +\left( \frac{M_{5}R}{z}\right)^2  e^{4kz^2/3} {\cal A}^{-2}  \,,
\end{eqnarray}

with ${\cal A}$ = $_0F_1(5/4, \frac{\Phi^2}{9})$. The normalizable solutions of Eq. \eqref{equ_7_new1} correspond to a discrete spectrum of $4d$ masses with the identification $q^2 = -m_n^2$. 
This equation was solved numerically in \cite{Li:2013oda}  for the scalar glueball $0^{++}$ and its radial (spin 0)  excitations and the masses found are compatible with those from lattice QCD.


\bigskip 

{\em Even spins and the pomeron.} From the AdS/CFT  dictionary one knows how to relate the operator in the super Yang-Mills theory with fields in the $AdS_{5} \times S^5$ space. For instance, the conformal dimension $\Delta$ of a super Yang-Mills operator is given by $\Delta = 2 + \sqrt{4 + M^2_{5}R^2}$. 

For a pure super Yang-Mills theory defined on the 4D boundary, one has that the scalar glueball state $0^{++}$ is represented by the operator ${\cal O}_4$, and it can be written as ${\cal O}_4 = Tr(F^2) = Tr(F^{\mu\nu}F_{\mu \nu})$.

From this expression one can note that the operator ${\cal O}_4$ has conformal dimension $\Delta = 4$, once $[Tr(F^2)] = M^4$ (mass fourth power). So, the lightest scalar glueball $0^{++}$ is dual to the fields with zero mass $(M^2_{5} = 0 )$ in the $AdS_5$ space.

For higher spin glueballs we insert symmetrized covariant derivatives in a given operator with spin $S$ in order to raise the total angular momentum, such that, the total angular momentum after the insertion is  $S+J$.
In the particular case of the spin zero operator ${\cal O}_4 = F^2$, one obtains ${\cal O}_{4 + J} = FD_{\lbrace\mu1 \cdots} D_{\mu J \rbrace}F$, with conformal dimension $\Delta = 4 + J$ and spin $J$. 
Using this approach and the expression  $\Delta = 2 + \sqrt{4 + M^2_{5}R^2}$, one has:
prevtext: \noindent and the equations of motion are:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\partial_{M}[\sqrt{-g_{s}}\;e^{-\Phi(z)}g^{MN}\partial_{N}{\cal G}]-\sqrt{-g_{%
s}}e^{-\Phi(z)}M^{2}_{5}{\cal G}=0\,." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mo>∂</mo><mi>M</mi></msub><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+2.8pt"><msqrt><mrow><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>g</mi><mi>s</mi></msub></mrow></msqrt></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>g</mi><mrow><mi>M</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>N</mi></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msub><mo>∂</mo><mi>N</mi></msub><mo>⁡</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒢</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msqrt><mrow><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>g</mi><mi>s</mi></msub></mrow></msqrt><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>M</mi><mn>5</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒢</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mn>0</mn></mpadded></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Associating the glueball state ${\cal G}$ with the operator  ${\cal O}_{4 + J}$ both with spin $J$, one has a 
 ``Schroedinger-like'' equation (\ref{equ_7_new1}) with a spin dependent effective potential, given by:
prevtext:
Representing the scalar field through a $4d$ Fourier transform ${\cal \tilde{G}}(q,z)$ and performing a change of function ${\cal \tilde{G}} = \psi (z) e^{\frac{B(z)}{2}}$, where $B(z) = \Phi(z) - 3A_s(z) $, one gets the following $1d$ Schr\"odinger-like equation

\begin{eqnarray}\label{equ_7_new1}
 - \psi''(z) + V(z) \psi(z) = (- q^2 )\psi(z)\,,
\end{eqnarray}
\noindent where the effective potential is given by 
\begin{eqnarray}\label{V(z)}
 V(z) =  k^2 z^2 + \frac{15}{4z^2}  - 2k 
 +\left( \frac{M_{5}R}{z}\right)^2  e^{4kz^2/3} {\cal A}^{-2}  \,,
\end{eqnarray}

with ${\cal A}$ = $_0F_1(5/4, \frac{\Phi^2}{9})$. The normalizable solutions of Eq. \eqref{equ_7_new1} correspond to a discrete spectrum of $4d$ masses with the identification $q^2 = -m_n^2$. 
This equation was solved numerically in \cite{Li:2013oda}  for the scalar glueball $0^{++}$ and its radial (spin 0)  excitations and the masses found are compatible with those from lattice QCD.


\bigskip 

{\em Even spins and the pomeron.} From the AdS/CFT  dictionary one knows how to relate the operator in the super Yang-Mills theory with fields in the $AdS_{5} \times S^5$ space. For instance, the conformal dimension $\Delta$ of a super Yang-Mills operator is given by $\Delta = 2 + \sqrt{4 + M^2_{5}R^2}$. 

For a pure super Yang-Mills theory defined on the 4D boundary, one has that the scalar glueball state $0^{++}$ is represented by the operator ${\cal O}_4$, and it can be written as ${\cal O}_4 = Tr(F^2) = Tr(F^{\mu\nu}F_{\mu \nu})$.

From this expression one can note that the operator ${\cal O}_4$ has conformal dimension $\Delta = 4$, once $[Tr(F^2)] = M^4$ (mass fourth power). So, the lightest scalar glueball $0^{++}$ is dual to the fields with zero mass $(M^2_{5} = 0 )$ in the $AdS_5$ space.

For higher spin glueballs we insert symmetrized covariant derivatives in a given operator with spin $S$ in order to raise the total angular momentum, such that, the total angular momentum after the insertion is  $S+J$.
In the particular case of the spin zero operator ${\cal O}_4 = F^2$, one obtains ${\cal O}_{4 + J} = FD_{\lbrace\mu1 \cdots} D_{\mu J \rbrace}F$, with conformal dimension $\Delta = 4 + J$ and spin $J$. 
Using this approach and the expression  $\Delta = 2 + \sqrt{4 + M^2_{5}R^2}$, one has:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="M^{2}_{5}R^{2}=J(J+4)\,;\qquad({\rm even}\,J)\,." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>M</mi><mn>5</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>J</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>J</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="22.5pt">;</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>even</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>J</mi></mrow><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
Associating the glueball state ${\cal G}$ with the operator  ${\cal O}_{4 + J}$ both with spin $J$, one has a 
 ``Schroedinger-like'' equation (\ref{equ_7_new1}) with a spin dependent effective potential, given by:

nexttext: Associating now the glueball state ${\cal G}$ with the operator  ${\cal O}_{6 + J}$ both with spin $J$, one has a Schr\"odinger-like equation  (\ref{equ_7_new1}) with a spin dependent effective potential, given by:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="M^{2}_{5}R^{2}=(J+6)(J+2)\,;\qquad({\rm odd}\,J)\,." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi>M</mi><mn>5</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>J</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>J</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="22.5pt">;</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>odd</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>J</mi></mrow><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: Associating now the glueball state ${\cal G}$ with the operator  ${\cal O}_{6 + J}$ both with spin $J$, one has a Schr\"odinger-like equation  (\ref{equ_7_new1}) with a spin dependent effective potential, given by:

nexttext:
The errors come from the linear fit. This Reege trajectory for the odderon is represented in Figure \ref{DSWodderon} and is in agreement with  \cite{LlanesEstrada:2005jf} within the non-relativistic constituent model.

\begin{figure}[h] 
  \centering
  \includegraphics[scale = 0.60]{DSW_odderon}
\caption{Regge trajectory for the odderon, Eq. \eqref{rpso}, from data of Table \ref{t2} with $k=0.1$ GeV$^2$ and  corresponding to the glueball states $ 1^{--}, 3^{--}, 5^{--}, 7^{--} $ and $9^{--}$.}
\label{DSWodderon}
\end{figure}









 

{\em Conclusions.} We used a dynamical holographic model  (DHM)  to describe even and odd spin glueballs and obtain the related Regge trajectories associated with the pomeron and the odderon, respectively. These trajectories are in good  agreement with those found in \cite{Capossoli:2015ywa, 
Capossoli:2013kb, LlanesEstrada:2005jf, BoschiFilho:2005yh, Landshoff:2001pp, Meyer:2004jc, Ballon-Bayona:2015wra}.  However, this is the first obtention of these Regge trajectories through a dynamical model. Also, this obtention leads us to solve some puzzles in previous phenomenological models. 

In particular, it has been shown in \cite{Capossoli:2015ywa} that the SWM could not lead to the expected Regge trajectories for the pomeron or the odderon. This problem is overcome in this Letter by the use of the DHM. 

The masses obtained in this work can be compared with the ones coming from some phenomenological models. First, the masses found here from the DHM are higher than those found from the SWM \cite{Capossoli:2015ywa}. This fact can be understood comparing the plots $V_J(z)\; \times\;  z$ for these two models. Figures \ref{plot1} and \ref{plot3} represent  the effective potential for the DHM for some even and odd spin glueball states while  \ref{plot2}  and \ref{plot4} represent the corresponding potentials for the softwall model. Since the minima of the effective potentials for the DHM are higher than those of the SWM, the corresponding masses eigenstates for the DHM are higher then those from the SWM. 

Second, the masses found from the DHM are similar to those found in refs. \cite{Capossoli:2013kb, BoschiFilho:2005yh} within the holographic hardwall model \footnote{This identification works better for the hardwall model with Neumann boundary condition, which has good agreement with experimental data.}. This fact can be understood also comparing Figures \ref{plot1} and \ref{plot3}  for the DHM with  \ref{plot2}  and \ref{plot4} for the SWM. One can see that in Figures \ref{plot1} and \ref{plot3} the effective potentials increase with larger slopes for each spin than those in \ref{plot2}  and \ref{plot4}. This means that the dynamical corrections of the SWM produce barriers for the effective potential similar to those of the phenomenological hardwall model. 

In ref. \cite{Meyer:2004jc}  it was argued that the state $0^{++}$ does not belong to the pomeron's Regge trajectory. Our results on the Regge trajectories for the pomeron, showed in Eqs. (\ref{rpsd}) and  (\ref{rpszsd}) are not conclusive in this regard. In Eq. (\ref{rpsd}) we obtain a Regge trajectory for the pomeron including the state $0^{++}$ which is agreement with \cite{Landshoff:2001pp} and \cite{Ballon-Bayona:2015wra}. On the other side, in Eq. (\ref{rpszsd}) we obtain a Regge trajectory for the pomeron excluding the state $0^{++}$ which is also compatible with experimental data \cite{Landshoff:2001pp}. 

In the case of the odderon, different Regge trajectories were found in \cite{LlanesEstrada:2005jf} corresponding  to a relativistic and a non-relativistic models. Our results from the DHM favors the non-relativistic model. Also, in ref. \cite{LlanesEstrada:2005jf} it was argued that the state $1^{--}$ should not belong to the odderon Regge trajectory. This conclusion is not supported by our results with the DHM for which the exclusion of the $1^{--}$ state does not lead to good Regge trajectories for the odderon.
